citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One 10-year-old female Cotton Top Tamarin (“Lola”) was found in critical condition (inactive in the bottom of her cage and
determined to be very skinny) on 6/26/23 by care staff. She was given subcutaneous fluids and staff sent emails informing
the attending and consulting veterinarians of her condition. Later in the day, the veterinarian responded directing staff to
obtain a fecal sample to send out to lab. Lola was found deceased in her enclosure on 6/28/23. For the 48 hours, from the
time this animal was found in critical condition to the time it had died, it had not been physically evaluated by a
veterinarian.
A necropsy revealed a moderate parasite load and facility representatives stated that it is not uncommon for them to find
this parasite in nonhuman primates at the facility. There is no parasite sampling strategy in place at the facility. The
consulting veterinarian has recommended monthly dosing with Albendazole for parasites but the facility does not follow
this treatment regime.
Lack of appropriate veterinary care, both preventative and emergency, can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals and
even death. The facility must ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and
injuries, and ensure the availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care.
To be corrected by September 6, 2023.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One 10-year-old female Cotton Top Tamarin (“Lola”) was found deceased in her enclosure on 6/28/23 after being found
inactive on 6/26/23 with a skinny body condition. A necropsy showed a moderate parasite load as well as muscle wasting,
lack of any subcutaneous or visceral fat, and malnutrition. There was no documentation or recognition of Lola’s decline in
body condition prior to 6/26/23.
Inadequate daily observations can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals when changes in their health are not noticed
in a timely manner. The facility must ensure that all animals are observed daily to assess their health and well-being and
then ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by September 6, 2023.

There was a crate of nine cauliflower in the walk-in cooler that were covered in brown-black patches. Earlier that day,
contaminated cauliflower from the crate were used to prepare soup for the nonhuman primates. Staff showed inspectors
the cooked soup which contained pieces of cauliflower with black discolored spots.
The ingestion of moldy or otherwise contaminated food can cause illness in the animals. Food must be clean, wholesome,
and palatable to the animals.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
When opening the door to “The Outback” building, a large number of roaches were seen in the door frame. The frame has
areas of deteriorated wood and holes that appear to be housing the roaches. Some of these roaches entered the building
where there are indoor enclosures for housing nonhuman primates.
Insect pests can carry parasites and various diseases that could compromise the health and well-being of nonhuman
primates. Licensees are responsible for maintaining buildings where housing facilities are located clean and in good repair
in order to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents, pests, and vermin.

Upon interviewing facility representatives, it was stated that optimal animal care cannot be administered due to staffing
shortages. This includes consistent veterinary care and other day to day tasks.
Insufficient staffing is a concern because it can negatively impact all areas of animal care and the well-being of the
animals. The licensee must have enough employees or other reliable trained staff to carry out the level of husbandry
practices and care required in this subpart.
To be completed in two phases; Phase 1: Develop a strategy for adequate employee recruitment. Phase 2: Trained
employees are carrying out husbandry practices and care as required in this subpart. Phase 1 to be corrected by October
18, 2023. Phase 2 to be corrected by December 20, 2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Patricia Laracuente, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One 10-year-old female Cotton Top Tamarin (“Lola”) was found in critical condition (inactive in the bottom of her cage and 
determined to be very skinny) on 6/26/23 by care staff. She was given subcutaneous fluids and staff sent emails informing 
the attending and consulting veterinarians of her condition. Later in the day, the veterinarian responded directing staff to 
obtain a fecal sample to send out to lab. Lola was found deceased in her enclosure on 6/28/23. For the 48 hours, from the 
time this animal was found in critical condition to the time it had died, it had not been physically evaluated by a 
veterinarian. 
 
A necropsy revealed a moderate parasite load and facility representatives stated that it is not uncommon for them to find 
this parasite in nonhuman primates at the facility. There is no parasite sampling strategy in place at the facility. The 
consulting veterinarian has recommended monthly dosing with Albendazole for parasites but the facility does not follow 
this treatment regime. 
 
Lack of appropriate veterinary care, both preventative and emergency, can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals and 
even death. The facility must ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and 
injuries, and ensure the availability of emergency, weekend, and holiday care. 
 
To be corrected by September 6, 2023. 
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One 10-year-old female Cotton Top Tamarin (“Lola”) was found deceased in her enclosure on 6/28/23 after being found 
inactive on 6/26/23 with a skinny body condition. A necropsy showed a moderate parasite load as well as muscle wasting, 
lack of any subcutaneous or visceral fat, and malnutrition. There was no documentation or recognition of Lola’s decline in 
body condition prior to 6/26/23.  
 
Inadequate daily observations can lead to the prolonged suffering of animals when changes in their health are not noticed 
in a timely manner. The facility must ensure that all animals are observed daily to assess their health and well-being and

then ensure a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian.  
 
To be corrected by September 6, 2023. 
3.82(a)  Repeat
   
Feeding. 
There was a crate of nine cauliflower in the walk-in cooler that were covered in brown-black patches. Earlier that day, 
contaminated cauliflower from the crate were used to prepare soup for the nonhuman primates. Staff showed inspectors 
the cooked soup which contained pieces of cauliflower with black discolored spots.  
 
The ingestion of moldy or otherwise contaminated food can cause illness in the animals. Food must be clean, wholesome, 
and palatable to the animals. 
3.84(c)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
When opening the door to “The Outback” building, a large number of roaches were seen in the door frame. The frame has 
areas of deteriorated wood and holes that appear to be housing the roaches. Some of these roaches entered the building 
where there are indoor enclosures for housing nonhuman primates.  
 
Insect pests can carry parasites and various diseases that could compromise the health and well-being of nonhuman 
primates. Licensees are responsible for maintaining buildings where housing facilities are located clean and in good repair 
in order to reduce or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents, pests, and vermin. 
3.85 
   
Employees. 
Upon interviewing facility representatives, it was stated that optimal animal care cannot be administered due to staffing 
shortages. This includes consistent veterinary care and other day to day tasks.  
 
Insufficient staffing is a concern because it can negatively impact all areas of animal care and the well-being of the 
animals. The licensee must have enough employees or other reliable trained staff to carry out the level of husbandry 
practices and care required in this subpart.  
 
To be completed in two phases; Phase 1: Develop a strategy for adequate employee recruitment. Phase 2: Trained 
employees are carrying out husbandry practices and care as required in this subpart. Phase 1 to be corrected by October 
18, 2023. Phase 2 to be corrected by December 20, 2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
